WE have said that, since we believe that God gave autonomy to His creation, we must also believe that in doing so He had power to realise His purpose by the method he had chosen.

The pregnant praise of the writer of Ι Peter, “a faithful creator‚'' cannot be read without re- minding us that creation must mean an obligation to another. In other words, we cannot think of God as creator and without obligation. From all that we know of life there is nothing worth having for which something must not be risked; but we know that it is not right for any one to risk more than he has to give, nor to allow that risk to in- volve others without the power to give compen- sation.
